Award.AwardTitle: Building a Community of Science Teacher Educators to Prepare Novices for Ambitious Science Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a growing consensus among science teacher educators of a need for a shared, research-based vision of accomplished instructional practice, and for teacher education pedagogies that can effectively prepare preservice science teachers to support the science learning of students from all backgrounds. This conference will bring together a group of teacher educators to focus on preservice teacher education and a shared vision of instruction called ambitious science teaching. This conference is a critical first step toward building a community of teacher educators who can collectively share and refine strategies, tools, and practices for preparing preservice science teachers for ambitious science teaching. The conference has two goals. The first goal is to develop a shared vision and language about effective pedagogy of science teacher preparation, focusing on ambitious science teaching and practice-based approaches to science teacher preparation. The second goal is to initiate a professional community that can generate, test, revise, and disseminate a set of resources (curriculum materials, tools, videos, models of teacher educator pedagogies, etc.) to support teacher educators. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

There are immediate and long-term broader impacts that will result from this conference. One immediate impact is that this conference will set forth an actionable research agenda for the participants and the field to take up around ambitious science teaching and practice-based teacher education. Such an agenda will help shape new work, involving institutional collaborations,teacher preparation programs, and national organizations. Such an outcome has the potential to immediately impact the work of the conference participants and their own teacher preparation programs. In the long-term, this conference provides an opportunity for the participants to consider how to use ambitious science teaching to address issues of equity and social justice in science education and schools. In addition, the broader impacts of this conference will be to spread a vision of science teaching and practice-based teacher preparation in which students' ideas and experiences are the raw material of teachers' work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was instrumental in helping to create and build a community of science teacher educators aimed at working together to design learning opportunities for preservice teachers to take up ambitious and equitable teaching. This project resulted in five important outcomes that will have immediate impact on science teacher education.

1)    In 2018, the conference - Ambitious Science Teacher Preparation (ASTP) took place at Michigan State University from June 4-7. The conference was also aided by student and staff assistants from the MSU College of Education, Department of Teacher Education, and the CREATE for STEM Institute housed at MSU. Colleagues from 14 institutions from across the United States attended. These colleagues included 16 faculty/directors of research, and 13 graduate students. In addition, over 85 people from across Michigan attended the first day of the conference to learn more about Ambitious Science Teaching (AST).

2)    In 2019, Ron Gray, a conference attendee, served as the organizer for a symposium at the annual meeting of the National Association of Research in Science Teaching (NARST). 5 conference attendees presented posters about topics we discussed at the conference. Approximately 40 people attended the session.

 

3)    A grant planning meeting at Vanderbilt University, which led to a proposal to the Spencer Foundation to examine preservice teacher learning across five institutions.

4)    In 2019, Co-PI Gotwals organized and led a meeting with four other conference attendees in East Lansing, MI at Michigan State University. The purpose of this meeting was to talk across multiple elementary science methods courses about ideas from the conference that they could investigate together as part of future research projects. At the meeting, they reviewed literature about pedagogies of elementary science methods courses, examined ideas from the conference about how to study methods courses, and began plotting a research trajectory to continue the work of the conference.

 

5)    In 2019-2020, we successfully submitted a book proposal submitted to Harvard Education Press which includes chapters by many conference attendees. The book will be published in November 2020, and is a direct result of this conference funding. Here is the link to the book on the Harvard Education Press website:

https://www.hepg.org/hep-home/books/preparing-science-teachers-through-practice-based#

Using the foundation built at the conference, participants plan to leverage resources and tools to improve their own teaching as well as to develop research projects to examine ways in which the Ambitious Science Teaching (AST) framework can be implemented in different teacher education contexts. Conference participants collaborated to refine conceptions of equity in AST, methods of attending to equity in AST, tools and strategies for preparing novice science teachers, as well as providing professional development for in-service teachers.  These clearer understandings of how AST can support all students to engage in science in the classroom and how to prepare teachers to utilize AST practices should support teacher educators in more effectively preparing teachers to utilize AST practices and attend to equity issues as they do so.
